column1: Dunedin  is a city in Pinellas County
column2: Florida
column3: United States. The name comes from Dùn Èideann
column4: the Scottish Gaelic name for Edinburgh
column5: the capital of Scotland. Dunedin is the 5th largest city in Pinellas County. The population was 35
column6: 321 at the 2010 census.Dunedin is home to several beaches
column10: which is consistently rated among the best beaches in the world. Dunedin is one of the few open waterfront communities from Sarasota to Cedar Key where buildings do not completely obscure the view of the Intracoastal Waterway and the Gulf of Mexico beyond; a 1-mile (1.6 km) stretch of Edgewater Drive (also known as Alternate US 19) south of downtown offers views of St. Joseph Sound
column12: and Caladesi Island. Downtown Clearwater and Clearwater Beach are a 6-mile (10 km) drive south on Edgewater.

column1: The downtown business district is notable for its absence of large commercial signage
column2: corporate franchise restaurants or chain retail stores. The Pinellas Trail
column3: a 39-mile-long (63 km) bicycle and pedestrian trail that traverses all of Pinellas County
column4: bisects downtown Dunedin.  A large portion of the trail lies on the former roadbed of the Orange Belt Railway
column5: the first railroad in Pinellas County

column2: Dunedin is the spring training home of the Toronto Blue Jays
column3: as well as the class-A Dunedin Blue Jays of the Florida State League. Dunedin is one of the smallest communities used by Major League spring training teams
column4: although surrounded by a large metropolitan area. TD Ballpark is situated next to the Dunedin Public Library a few blocks south of downtown on Douglas Avenue
column5: and is just two blocks east of Edgewater Drive.  The stadium was built as a replacement to Grant Field
column6: the Blue Jays' first spring training ball park. The library was founded in 1895 and is the oldest public library in Pinellas County.Until early 2005
column7: Dunedin was the home of Nielsen Media Research's production operations. The city is home to multiple breweries including Dunedin Brewery

column2: which is the approximate geographic center of the city. The middle of downtown (intersection of Main Street and Douglas Avenue) is located at 28°00′42″N 82°47′16″W.According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 28.2 square miles (73 km2). 10.4 square miles (27 km2) of it is land and 17.8 square miles (46 km2) of it (63.20%) is water.

column1: Dunedin is bordered by the city of Clearwater to the south and east
column2: the Gulf of Mexico to the west
column3: and by Palm Harbor (an unincorporated community of Pinellas County) to the north.

column1: Dunedin previously hosted an office of Nielsen Media Research. In 2003 the company consolidated its employees in a new complex in Oldsmar
column2: Florida
column3: with workers from Dunedin and other areas in Pinellas County moving into the Oldsmar Building.TD Ballpark and Englebert Complex are used by the Dunedin Blue Jays and spring training facilities for the Toronto Blue Jays since 1977. TD Ballpark was built on the former Grant Field c. 1930.

column1: Dunedin has been accused of draconian fines towards its residents. In one case
column2: it is suing a former resident over a hundred thousand dollars for yard and swimming pool maintenance. There are cases where the city has charged tens of thousands of dollars over uncut grass or aesthetic city code violations. The city has a $250 to $500 per day accruing violation policy per city code § 22-79(d). "In 5½ years
column3: the city has collected nearly $3.6 million in fines
column4: sometimes tens of thousands at a time
column5: for violating laws that prohibit grasses taller than 10 inches
column6: recreational vehicles parked on streets at certain hours or sidings and bricks that don't match."

column1: Dunedin's major highway US Route 19 Alternate connects the city with the rest of Florida
column2: while Main Street and Pinellas County Road 1 provides local connections.

column1: The closest airport is St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport located southeast of Dunedin.
Richard L. Garrison was the first person given a land grant in Dunedin in 1852. The settlement was originally named Jonesboro by George Jones
column2: the owner of the area mercantile. Two Scotsmen
column3: J.O. Douglas and James Somerville
column4: later named the settlement Dunedin after applying for the first post office in northern Pinellas County. The name is taken from Scottish Gaelic Dùn Èideann
column5: the Scottish Gaelic for Edinburgh. With a dock built to accommodate larger sailing vessels
column6: Dunedin became an important trading center and at one time it had the largest fleet of sailing vessels in the state.

column1: Dunedin became incorporated as a town in 1899 in part as a response to numerous complaints about pigs running rampant in the settlement
column2: leading to a still-standing ban on livestock within city limits. By 1913
column3: the town had a population of only 350. It became incorporated as the City of Dunedin in 1925.

column1: During and shortly before World War II the Food Machinery Corporation factory in Dunedin (now demolished) was the primary site for the production of the Landing Vehicle Tracked developed by FMC Dunedin's Engineers and Donald Roebling of Clearwater from Roebling's own Alligator.Initial training on the LVTs was done at the FMC factory under the auspices of the first Amphibian Tractor School
column2: led by Major William W. Davies. Until barracks and maintenance facilities were completed
column3: the school and its students were housed in the Hotel Dunedin. After training
column4: the Marines from the first Amphibian Tractor School were sent to flesh out the 1st Amphibian Tractor Battalion
column5: which has served with distinction since. In mid-1944
column6: the Marine unit in Dunedin was transferred to Camp Pendleton

column2: the Fenway Hotel is a historic hotel (c. 1927) that saw many famous guests throughout its lifetime.

column2: Scotland
column3: Dunedin has maintained and embraced its Scottish roots. Once a year
column4: Scottish clans descend upon the city for the Dunedin Highland Games. Both Dunedin High School and Dunedin Highland Middle School have competition-level pipe and drum bands. The high school's marching band is known as the Scottish Highlander Band
column5: and both teen and adult members make up the City of Dunedin Pipe Band.

column1: In addition to the Highland Games
column2: Dunedin hosts many other annual festivals. The most popular among these is Dunedin's Mardi Gras celebration
column3: during which thousands of visitors descend on the small town.

The City of Dunedin currently operates under a nonpartisan commissioner-manager form of government. The commission comprises four commissioners and a mayor
column2: who are elected by the registered voters under a staggered system.The chief executive officer
column3: known as the city manager
column4: oversees the ten departments and the annual budget.

column2: the Dunedin City Commission is made up of Mayor Julie Ward Bujalski
column3: Vice-mayor Heather Gracy
column4: Commissioner Maureen "Moe" Freaney
column5: Commissioner Deborah Kynes
column6: and Commissioner Jeff Gow. The city manager is Jennifer Bramley.

column1: The city government is made up of ten departments with various divisions and sections. The departments are Administration
column2: Human Resources
column3: Information Services
column4: Public Works
column5: Parks & Recreation
column10: Planning/Development and Finance. The Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA) oversees downtown projects and the needs of downtown Dunedin merchants and tourism.

column1: Dunedin boasts an extensive Volunteer Services section
column2: and enables all citizens the chance to have their opinions expressed and tended to. Currently
column3: there are 39 boards and committees that serve as advisory groups to the city manager and the City Commission.

column1: Dunedin Fire Department has 48 firefighters split into 16 members over three shifts. The department has 3 fire stations proving fire protection for Dunedin.
Pinellas County Sheriff Office's North District Patrol provides law enforcement for Dunedin.
The city of Dunedin contains a Parks & Recreation Department
column2: which provides low-cost recreation programming to the city's residents. The city operates four recreation facilities
column3: each one designed to provide resources for a specific age group.

column2: Dunedin opened its newest and largest recreation facility
column3: the Dunedin Community Center at a cost of just over $10 million. The project was mostly paid for by the "Penny for Pinellas" tax. The St. Petersburg Times wrote that Marston "figured that since the county needs recreation programs of its own and the city needs a new community center
column4: why not ask the county to pay for the project in exchange for access to the new facility." Marston's proposal marked a turning point for the city as it saved Dunedin taxpayers millions
column5: and allowed Dunedin officials to replenish vital strategic reserves. The center features classrooms / multi-purpose rooms
column15: opened in 1975 has grown to be one of the most renowned centers for visual art instruction and exhibition in the southeastern United States. At nearly 40
column20: the Palm Cafe and the DLM Children's ART Museum. Tampa Bay Times writer Lennie Bennett says that DFAC is “the artistic equivalent of a village square
column21: ” offering quality experiences to people of all ages.

Dunedin Country Club - a semi-private golf course with memberships available and the course is open to the public. The course was deeded to the city of Dunedin for recreational purposes in 1930 by the Contract Investment Company.The city has a large athletic base
column2: with community soccer
column3: baseball
column4: hockey
column5: and softball teams. Dunedin reflected the Gaelic origins of its name by playing host to a short lived American shinty club

column1: In 2011 the City of Dunedin passed ordinance 2011-04 which authorized the street-legal use of golf carts across approximately 60% of the city.City owned parks include:
Edgewater Park and Playground - waterfront park with marinas and kayak launch area
Elizabeth Skinner-Jackson Park and Playground - features a basketball court
Hammock Park and Playground - located next to baseball fields used by Greater Dunedin Little League
Josiah Cephas Weaver Park and Playground
Martin Luther King Jr. Recreation Center and Playground
VFW PlaygroundHoneymoon Island State Park and Caladesi Island State Park are located in Dunedin along St. Joseph Sound on the west side.

The city-owned Dunedin Marina has 194 boat slips and is one of the finest municipal marinas on the West Coast of Florida. The marina is located on the intercoastal waterway between Dunedin Causeway and Clearwater Causeways. It is home to the Dunedin Boat Club
column2: one of Florida's oldest Sailing Clubs.

column1: The Dunedin Public Library has two branches
column2: the Dunedin Main Library (located at 223 Douglas Ave) and the Friends Branch Library (located at 1920 Pinehurst Road)
column3: which opened in 2007. The library is considered the oldest library in Pinellas County. In 1895 Christopher B Bouton
column4: a resident from Cleveland
column5: gave the city of Dunedin 200 books for public use. Mr. Bouton’s brother owned the town’s meeting hall but gave ownership of it to the Dunedin Library Association to house the public library and a reading room. The building became known thereafter as Library Hall. In 1935
column6: the City of Dunedin took over the Library when the collection grew to be 7
column7: 000 titles. As the population of Dunedin and the usage of the library grew
column8: the facility was in need of more space. Two new libraries were built
column9: one in 1956 on Louden Avenue and another in 1964 on Main Street. In 1976 the Library leased and moved into a vacant space in the Douglas Plaza Shopping Center
column10: which was purchased by the City of Dunedin for the Library in 1986. In 1989
column11: the estate of Franklin Chase Milliken
column13: was left to the City of Dunedin to benefit the Dunedin Public Library. After years of planning
column14: the City Commission approved funding for a 38
column16: costing approximately $3.5 million. Soon after the Library’s centennial in April 1995
column17: the collection was moved into trailers while the old building was torn down and a new one was built in the same location. The new building opened to the public on September 3
column18: 1996.As part of their offerings and services
column19: the Dunedin Public Library offers monthly delivery service to homebound residents of Dunedin. Other offerings include a seed library where patrons can check out seeds for gardening
column21: and genealogy assistance.  The Dunedin Public Library initiated a Little Free Library movement in Pinellas County. There are currently thirteen Little Free Libraries within Dunedin. The Literacy Council of Upper Pinellas
column23: which promotes adult literacy in North Pinellas County
